results.title: Le Diable Boiteux = the Devil with a Limp
results.brief_description:
Sacha Guitry used Talleyrand’s nickname ‘the Devil with a limp’ as the starting point for a film on the first ‘Eurocrat’ and his life full of ups and downs, conspiracies and betrayals of every sort. From the Ancien Regime by whom Talleyrand was elevated to Bishop of Autun up to the reign of Louis-Philippe when he negotiated the peace with Britain, the path of this most famous political opportunist was played to the music of infidelity and the thirst for power. Talleyrand’s grand passions (money, women and power…) are filmed with outstanding cinematic finesse.

Credits: Producer, Jean Mugeli ; director, Sacha Guitry ; writer, Sacha Guitry ; photography, Nicolas Toporkoff ; music, Louis Beydts.
Cast: Pierre Bertin, Pauline Carton, Daniel Ceccaldi, Jean Debucourt, Emile Drain, Maurice Escande, Jeanne Fusier-Gir, Sacha Guitry, Robert Hossein, Lana Marconi, Jose Noguero, Jean Piat, Maurice Schutz, Renee Devillers.

results.title: Le Destin de Juliette = the Destiny of Juliette
results.brief_description:
Aline Isserman’s film chronicles twenty years of a woman’s life. Juliette, a simple country girl, is in love with Pierre, a sheperd but she is forced into a marriage with a boring railway worker in order to save her family from poverty and homelessness. The husband, Marcel, is transferred from post to post, and becomes an alcoholic, eventually dying, leaving Juliette free to rebuild her life.

Credits: Producer, Eric Lambert ; director, Aline Isserman ; writers, Michel Dufresne, Aline Isserman ; photography, Dominique Le Rigoleur ; music, Bernard Lubat.
Cast: Laure Duthilleul, Richard Bohringer, Veronique Silver, Pierre Forget, Hippolyte Girardot.

results.title: Le Desordre et Apres (1960-1966) Part 11
results.brief_description:
Part 11 of 13 part series on the history of French cinema. By the mid-1960s the industry had reconciliated. The French filmgoing public, and most producers, had lost their sympathy for formal experiment and unbridled self-expression. But it would be an exaggeration to argue that French cinema was essentially unchanged, and that most of the films of the late 1960s resembled those of the previous decade. Much had, in fact, been irretrievably altered. The film community was no longer closed to new talent. New directors (for example, Constantin Costa-Gavras, in 1965) and other personnel entered the industry with much greater ease than during the ‘Tradition of Quality’, though most of them worked on unadventurous, if occasionaly stylish, commercial projects.” Reference: Alan Williams. ‘Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking’. Harvard University Press, 1992 Our collection holds many of the titles referred to in this episode. Apart from a large selection of works by Truffaut, Melville, Chabrol and Godard of this particular decade, we also recommend the following: Rohmer’s ‘Le signe du Lion’ ; Astruc’s ‘La proie pour l’ombre’ and ‘La longue marche’ ; Franju’s ‘La tete contre les murs’ and ‘Judex’ ; Varda’s ‘Le bonheur’ and ‘Cleo de 5 a 7’ ; Michel Drach’s ‘On n’enterre pas le dimanche’ and ‘Amelie ou le temps d’aimer’ ; Resnais’s ‘L’annee derniere a Marienbad’ and ‘La guerre est finie’ ; Colpi’s ‘Une aussi longue absence’ ; Deville’s ‘Ce soir ou jamais’ and ‘Adorable menteuse’ ; Robert Enrico’s ‘Au coeur de la vie’ ; Alain Robbe-Grillet’s ‘L’immortelle’, ‘L’homme qui ment’ and ‘Glissement progressifs du plaisir’ ; Henri Verneuil’s ‘Melodie en sous-sol’.

Credits: Director, Armand Panigel ; photography, Claude Cassard.
Cast: Includes interviews with: Louis Malle, Pierre Granier-Deferre, Pierre Kast, Claude Chabrol, Alain Robbe-Grillet, Eric Rohmer.

results.title: Le Desordre a Vingt Ans = Disorder Is Twenty Years Old
results.brief_description:
In this documentary, Jacques Baratier compares life in the St Germain des Pres area of Paris in the the post WWII years and 20 years later in the Sixties (pre May 68). Rare documents and seldom seen footage of personalities, “overexposed films shot in obscure places” such as ‘Le Tabou’ recreate the ambiance of the great existentialist era. The interviewees recall the social changes that led to the movement. They include: Boris Vian, Alain Vian, Roger Blin, Juliette Greco, Raymond Queneau, Jean Cau, Simone de Beauvoir, Jean-Paul Sartre, Sophie Desmarets, Jean Cocteau, Roger Pierre, Arthur Adamov, Cesar, Anne-Marie Cazalis, Michel de Re, Roger Vadim, Annabel, Gabriel Pomerand, Sydney Bechet, Claude Luter etc… This film is followed by ‘Voila l’ordre’.

Credits: Director, Jacques Baratier.

results.title: Le Dernier Scalp
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Le Tresor des Hollandais”.
Stephane is so filled with guilt that he wants to reveal all to Olympe before he gets her compromised further. The second substitution of jewels turns out to just as problematic as the first one. The children return the necklace to the props department of the Opera House. Jacinthe is allowed to keep a ring from the treasure, much to Lulu’s dismay.

Credits: Director, Philippe Agostini; writer, Odette Joyeux; photography, Christian Petard; music, Georges Auric; choreography, Michel Descombey; costumes, Pierre Balmain.
Cast: Claude Bessy, Claude Ariel, Catherine Bouchy, Pierre Didier, Felix Marten, Jacques Fabbri, Robert Manuel.

results.title: Le Dernier Saut = the Last Leap
results.brief_description:
Gara has just been demobbed from the paratroopers and is looking forward to resuming life at home with his wife. On his arrival he discovers his whife in the arms of another man. Seething with rage, he starts to conceive a plan to murder her. An iron-clad alibi is provided by fellow paratroopers and when the investigation concludes, the young lover is found guilty of the murder. Gara is overwhelmed with guilt and the longer he remains silent about the crime, the more psychological torture he must endure.

Credits: Producer, Raymond Danon ; director, Edouard Luntz ; writers, Antoine Blondin, Roland Girard, Jean Bovary, Edouard Luntz ; photography, Jean Badal ; music, Eugene Kurtz.
Cast: Maurice Ronet, Michel Bouquet, Cathy Rosier, Betty beckers.

results.title: Le Dernier Milliardaire = the Last Millionaire
results.brief_description:
Le Dernier Milliardaire’ tells the story of a small mythical European country, Casinario, suddenly subjected to the whims of a mad dictator. Tobis Klangfilm refused to bankroll the project on political grounds, worried it could be considered a commentary on Hitler’s recent seizure of power in Germany. (Clair’s script also contained some fairly overt parodic references to Mussolini.) And so the (by now financially ailing) Pathe-Natan company had the bad fortune to produce what most observers consider the one complete failure among all of Clair’s works, a film scorned by audiences and critics alike as unfunny, tasteless, and cinematographically inept, although it is a sheer delight today. Unnerved by this commercial disaster, Clair left France for an artistic exile in England and, during the war years, the United States. It would be thirteen eventful years before his return to the French cinema, as an old master in the postwar ‘Tradition de Qualite’. Reference: Alan Williams. “Republic of Images: a history of French filmmaking”. Harvard University Press, 1992.

Credits: Director, Rene Clair ; writer, Rene Clair ; photography, Rudolph Mate, Louis Nee ; music, Maurice Jaubert ; art direction, Lucien Aguettand, Lucien Carre.
Cast: Max Dearly, Renee Saint-Cyr, Marthe Mellot, Jose Noguero, Charles Redgie, Jean Sinoel, Raymond Cordy, Christian Argentin, Marcel Carpentier.

results.title: Le Dernier Matin D'albert Camus
results.brief_description:
The life and work of Albert Camus, Nobel prize-winning novelist, playwright, journalist and essayist. This short documentary returns to places that have played a important role in Camus’ life; the ruins of Tippasa, his home in Lourmarin as well as the theatre which was to be his refuge from the trappings of celebrity. It is illustrated with a lengthy interview with the author. Also available in the NLA Collection (#2002445, 16mm).

Credits: Director, Harry Fishbach ; writers, Daisy Loriaux, Jean-Claude Brisville ; photography, Jean-Marie Boussaguet ; music, Rene Thomas, Maurice Jarre.
Cast: Text by Albert Camus interpreted by Michel Auclair, narration by Jacques Harden.

results.title: Le Dejeuner Sur L'herbe = Picnic in the Grass
results.brief_description:
Jean Renoir never made any secret that ‘Le Dejeuner sur L’Herbe’ was inspired by the impressionist paintings of his father Auguste Renoir, and also of Edouard Monet. A pompous Parisian professor concerned with artificial insemination, finds himself seduced by the mysteries of the countryside and the farmer’s daughter. Shot almost entirely at Les Collettes, the Renoir family home near Cannes, its sensuous colours and sunlit images derive from the Impressionists.

Credits: Producer, Ginette Doynel ; director, Jean Renoir ; writer, Jean Renoir ; photography, Georges Leclerc ; music, Joseph Kosma.
Cast: Paul Meurisse, Catherine Rouvel, Fernand Sardou, Ingrid Nordine.

results.title: Le Defile de Poncarbo = the Gorges of Poncarbo
results.brief_description:
Episode 5 of Series “Lagardere”.
Following his humiliation at the Regent’s ball, Philippe de Gonzague flees the court, taking Flor and Aurore as hostages. On his way to Spain, Gonzague and his aides stop at an inn. There they plot to assassinate their pursuant with the help of local ruffians.

Credits: Producer, Robert Velin ; director, Jean-Pierre Decourt ; writers, Marcel Jullian, Jean-Pierre Decourt ; photography, Georges Barsky ; music, Jacques Loussier.
Cast: Jean Piat, Jacques Dufilho, Jean-Pierre Darras, Nadine Alari, Jacques Balutin, Claude Confortes, Marco Perrin

group_siblings.title: Le Bal du Regent = the Regent's Ball
Le Petit Parisien = the Little Parisian
Les Noces du Bossu = the Wedding of the Hunchback
